name: Set Theme
info:
This subflow selects post(s) from MySQL database. The blog postId given can be given in
msg.req.params.postId which results in a single post populating the msg.post object. If
msg.req.params.postId is not given the subflow will select all posts from the 
blog_posts table and populate msg.posts (note the 's' in posts). This subflow also
includes the partials subflow required to display site web pages.

### Inputs
Input is taken from msg.req.params.postId which assumes the subflow is called
from a flow that received the post ID from an HTTP request.

As mentioned above, not given a post ID will select all posts from the blog_posts table.

### Outputs
  * msg.post
    * The title, author, and body of the post ID requested
        * Displays list of all blog posts
  * msg.posts (optional)
    * Array of all posts from database - if msg.req.params.postId not given
  * msg.page
    * The partials (navbar, footer, etc.) required of the site web pages.

name: Builder Theme
info:
This subflow places partials (navbar, footer, etc.) into *msg.pages*, which is used
to provide the standard framework of the Blog web site pages.

### Inputs
  * No inputs expected

### Outputs
  * msg.page
    * Header, Footer, etc for use by Mustache to inject in all Blog site pages.

name: Set standard HTML that is on web pages (styles, navigation, footer, etc.)
Web Page JS functions and theme selection
Click on comments and look at the  INFO tab of the side bar for handy info
About subflows
info:
Node-RED subflows provide important features for the Blog site.

### Simplify flow wiring
No matter how complex a subflow is, it appears as a single node with-in the flow 
that is using it. Subflows assist in simplifing wiring flow diagrams of complex
systems.

### Re-use of common processes
A subflow can be designed to handle a common re-usable process. It is not unusual to have
the same flow to be used numerous times while building higher level flows
of an application.

Subflows can also have nodes which check for [edge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edge_case)
cases and re-direct what nodes with-in the subflow that will be executed for that specific
edge case. The high level flows which use the subflow are oblivious to the underlying
details in handling the process - as long as the subflow returns the expected result.

### Common code base
By placing a function, template, or node into a subflow, changes to those nodes
take effect for all higher level flows that use that subflow.

By changing a subflow, that modified code will immediately effect
all flows that use that subflow. Thus any change in a single node with-in the
subflow will change it everywhere the subflow is used.

*For example:* the blog _Page Layout_ subflow contains the content that will be inserted
(by Mustache) into all web pages. By making a change (let's say the site name) in
the _Page Layout_ subflow, all higher level flows that use the subflow will now
reflect that name change.

*Note:* For Mustache - In template lingo this is called **partials**. Node-RED does
not implement the 'partial' system defined by Mustache, but this can be easly simulated
by placing the style, header, footer, etc. HTML markup in the message being passed to nodes.
In our case, the _Page Layout_ subflow puts the HTML code into the **msg.page** object
which is passed from node to node.

### Subflows can use other subflows
A subflow can use other subflows. This feature allows multi-level encapsulation of tasks.
When designing and building subflows consider making the subflow as generic as possible 
(ie: data based).

name: Flow/Dataflow based programming
info:
Node-Red is a high level,
[flow based](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flow-based_programming) programming
language. It is used to describe
[dataflow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dataflow_programming) movement between
independent synchronous and asynchronous processes.

Each node-red procedure is called a `flow`. Flows are created from one or
more discreet processes called `nodes` which can have none, one, or more input/output
`ports`. The transmission of data consist of `wires` between ports which
determine the path of `msg` javascript data objects.

Programming applications in node-red is performed via a graphical interface 
called the `Editor`. The Editor is divided into three panels named `Palette`,
`Flows`, and `Sidebar`. The Palette panel contains the nodes available to the
application, the Flows panel is where nodes are configured and wired into flows,
while Sidebar _tabs_ display documentation and debug information.

Editor options for the panels is in the menu in the upper-right hand side of the
interface.

The Palette contains the list of the nodes that have been installed and enabled
for use by the application. Under the menu




For the most part `ports` are transparent to the programming of a flow.
They depict are the endpoints used to wire nodes together.
They
represent if the node accepts an input or output `wire`. *For example:*
If a node does not have an input port - then

### Applications

Applications are built up based upon one or more `flows`. Regardless of the
complexity of the application, the processing and flow of data is controlled
by using these three fundamental objects, `node`, `port`, and `wire`.


To start the processing
of a flow requires some type of _input_ trigger. Most input nodes do not have an
in bound port. Node-red provides a set of default
input triggers. nodes are called _input_
is

name: Blog home page
info:
This page uses the *Get Post(s)* subflow to get the posts from the blog_posts
MySQL table. Since it does not pass the post ID in msg.req.params.postId,
*Get Post(s)* returns all posts in _msg.posts_ object, which is passed onto
the _Blog Home_ web page template which uses Mustache to inject *msg.page* and
*msg.posts* data into the page.

The web page is created using the standard node-red `template` node with
Mustache which injects the variable data.

name: Create / Edit a blog post
info:
This page uses the *Page Layout* subflow to add the site standard
header, navbar, footer, etc.

The web page is created using the standard node-red `template` node with
Mustache which injects the variable data.

name: Display a blog post
info:
This page uses the *Get Post(s)* subflow to get the posts from the blog_posts
MySQL table. It has the post ID in msg.req.params.postId thus *Get Post(s)*
subflow returns that post in _msg.post_ object, which is passed onto
the _Edit a post_ web page template which uses Mustache to inject *msg.page* and
the post *msg.post* data into the page.

It also uses the Markup body subflow which takes the text from the body of the
post and runs it through the *marked* package to markup the body from Markdown
text to HTML.

The web page is created using the standard node-red `template` node with
Mustache which injects the variable data.

name: Credits page
info:
This page is a simple page that uses the *Page Layout* subflow to add the
site standard header, navbar, footer, etc.

The web page is created using the standard node-red `template` node with
Mustache which injects the variable data.

name: Web Site Builder
info:
There are five [get] pages and two [post] processes to run the blog site.

The home page displays links to the list of posts, credits page of kudos, and the 
display/creation/editing of blog posts.

The HTTP [post] requests update the database
and then display the appropriate **blog post** page.

*Note:* Some confusion can happen between the HTTP method **[post]** and a **blog _post_**. In
node descriptions and documentation the **HTTP _[get]_ **and** _[post]_ ** methods are encloded in square-brackets [].

### Inputs
Inputs are in the form of HTTP requests. Where appropriate the post ID is passed as a parameter
in the request to get the post information from the database.

### Outputs
  * HTML pages
    * Blog Home
        * Displays list of all blog posts
    * Create new post
        * Edit page '/edit' without a post ID
    * Edit existing post
        * Edit page given a post ID
            * '/edit/:postId'
    * Blog Credits page
        * Thanks crediting developers, packages, and services
    * Post page
        * Displays the title, author, and body of a post


  * Processes (see _Blog Site Processes_ comment for more details)
    * [Post] '/post'
        * Insert new blog post into database
        * Return page that displays that post
    * [Post] '/post/:postId'
        * Update existing blog post on database 
        * Return page that displays updated post

name: Views
info:
There are four pages in the Blog site. Create and Edit a blog post use the same web page.

The home page displays links to the list of posts, credits page of kudos, and the 
display/creation/editing of blog posts.

### Inputs
Inputs are in the form of HTTP requests. Where appropriate the post ID is passed as a parameter
in the request to get the post information from the database.

### Outputs
  * HTML pages
    * Blog Home
        * Displays list of all blog posts
    * Create new post
        * Edit page '/edit' without a post ID
    * Edit existing post
        * Edit page given a post ID
            * '/edit/:postId'
    * Blog Credits page
        * Thanks crediting developers, packages, and services
    * Post page
        * Displays the title, author, and body of a post

### Details
The pages use Mustache to inject HTML header, footer, etc. into each page
from the *msg.page* object. All pages but the Credits page access the 
database to get the data to inject into the pages.

The Credits page is the simplest of all the pages.

<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1, shrink-to-fit=no">
<meta name="description" content="">
<meta name="author" content="">
<title id="page-title"></title>

    body {background-color: aliceblue;}
    .page-header {background-color: #e3f1ff}

    pre code {white-space: pre;overflow-x: auto; background:ghostwhite;}
    blockquote {font-size: 1em;}
    .btn-outline-primary {margin: 0 .5rem 0 0;}
    #menu-toggle {float:left; text-decoration: none;}
    .know-more {font-size: .8em;}
    .sb-icon {background: white;}
    .fa {display: inline;}
</style>

name: Scripts
template:
<script>
$(function () {
    <!-- Menu Toggle Script -->
    $('a').click(function(e) { 
        // If the show/hide menu button then toggle the sidebar
        if (e.target.id === 'menu-toggle' || this.id === 'menu-toggle') {
            e.preventDefault();
            $("#wrapper").toggleClass("toggled");
        }
        // Give time for the sidebar to collapse before going to link
        else if ($("#wrapper").hasClass("toggled")) {
            e.preventDefault();                   // prevent default anchor behavior
            var goTo = this.getAttribute("href"); // store anchor href
            $("#wrapper").toggleClass("toggled",false);
            setTimeout(function() {
                 window.location = goTo;
            },500);
        }
    });
});
</script>
